20/02/2025, 6:21â€¯am - +92 334 3839983: 1. â€œJabir b. Samura reported: The Messenger of Allah (may peace be upon him) came to us and said: How is it that I see you lifting your hands like the tails of headstrong horses? Be calm in prayerâ€( Sahih Muslim, Chapter 24 : The Command To Observe Prayer With Tranquillity, Also mentioned in Nasai, Abu-Dawood, Musnad Imam Ahmed, Tahavi).

According to Maulana Faiz Ahmed, this is a clear indication that tranquility is necessary in prayers rather than raising hands. He further explains that the Arabic phrase â€œFi Salat i.e. In prayerâ€ refers to the actions that are performed during the prayers rather then the ones at the start and at the end.


2. â€œHannaad - Wakee' - Sufyaan - Aasim bin Kulaib -Abdur Rahmaan bin Al Aswad - Alqamah who said: Abdullah Bin Mas'ood (radhiyallahu anhu) said: Should I not perform with you the Salaat of Rasulullah (Sallallahu alayhi wa Sallam)?'He (Ibn Mas'ood) then performed Salaat and he did not raise his hands except in the beginning once.â€ (Tirmizi, Part 1 Pg 35, Abu Dawood, Part 1 Pg. 116, Nasai, Part 1, Pg 161, Mahla Ibn-e-Hazm Zahiri, Daara Qutni, Baheqi, Musannaf Abi Shaibah, Muatta Imam Muhammad, Musnad â€“e- Ahmad, Tahavi,)

This hadeeth has been termed as hassan by Imam Tirmizi and Ibn-e-Hazm has categorized it as sahih as mentioned by Hafiz Ibn-e-Hajr (AL-Takhlees al Hajr Ala Sharah Madhab, Part 3, p.g. 274)


3. â€œAbdullah Ibn-e-Umar reported: I saw Prophet (Peace Be Upon Him), When he started prayers he raised his hands upto the level of both shouldersâ€¦.. And when he intended to do â€˜Rukuâ€™ and when he raised his head after â€˜Rukuâ€™ he did not raise his handsâ€ (Sahih Abu â€˜Awana, Book 2 Page 90, Musnad Humaidi, Part 2, Page 277)

Muhadith Abu Awana is among students of Imam Muslim [ra]. In his book he did research work on Sahih Muslim and collected more â€œsanadsâ€ for ahadeeth in Muslim. Imam Humaidi was the teacher of Imam Bukhari (Bustan-ul-Muhaditheen, 98, 95). As per Maulana Faiz Ahmed, Both these two very learned people have considered the hadeeth as sahih which is a clear evidence of authenticity of Tarke-Rafa Yadain.

4. â€œNarrated Al-Bara' ibn Azib: When the Apostle of Allah (peace_be_upon_him) began prayer, he raised his hands up to his ears, then he did not repeat.â€ (Abu Dawood, Part 1 Pg 116, Tahawi, Daara Qutni, Musannaf Abi Shaibah)

5. Abdullah (Ibn Mas'ood - radhiyallahu anhu) said: I performed Salaat with Nabi (Sallallahu alayhi wa Sallam), with Abu Bakr and Umar (radhiyallahu anhuma). They did not raise their hands except at the time of the first Takbeer in the opening of the Salaat. (Daara Qutni, Ibn- Adi, Bahiqi)

6. Narrated AbuHurayrah: When the Apostle of Allah (peace_be_upon_him) began his prayer, he raised his hands extensively. (Abu Dawood, Part 1 pg 116 ).

Maulana Faiz comments that this hadeeth only mentions about raising hands at the start of prayer and does not contain an indication of doing raising hands at the time of ruku that is the reason why Imam Abu Dawood [ra] includes this hadeeth in the appropriate chapter.

7. Hazrat Aswad, Reports: I have seen Hazrat Umar [rd] he raised his hands at the first takbeer and did not repeat. (Musannaf Ibn Abi Shaibah, Part 1, P.g. 237, Tahawi, Part 1, p.g. 133) This hadeeth has authentic chain and as per Hafiz Ibn-e-Hajr[ra] the chain is reliable (Ad-daraya, pg 152) Authentic as per the condition of Imam Muslim (Al Johar annaqi ala sunan Baheqi, part 2, p.g. 75) Authetic Chain (Umdat-ul-Qari Sharah Bukhari, Part 5 Pg. 273)Authentic as per Imam Tahavi (Tahawi, Part 1, p.g. 133 )

Imam Nasaai narrates ahadeeth in his book concerning rafa-yadain and then he adds a chapter after them with heading "abandoning of this (Rafa-yadain)". In this chapter he includes the hadeeth of Ibne-Masud (rd)

Sahih Muslim 2882 a
Harith b Abi Rabi'a and 'Abdullah b. Safwan both went to Umm Salama, the Mother of the Faithful, and they asked her about the army which would be sunk in the earth, and this relates to the time when Ibn Zubair (was the governor of Mecca). She reported that Allah's Messenger (ï·º) had said that a seeker of refuge would seek refuge in the Sacred House and an army would be sent to him (in order to kill him) and when it would enter a plain ground, it would be made to sink. I said:

Allah's Messenger, what about him who would be made to accompany this army willy nilly? Thereupon he said: He would be made to sink along with them but he would be raised on the Day of Resurrection on the basis of his intention. Abu Ja'far said. ' This plain, ground means the plain ground of Medina.

05/03/2025, 11:04â€¯pm - Syed Abdullah: Asslamualikum, is this hadith authentic?

Sunan Ibn Majah 3719
It was narrated that Umm Salamah said:
"Abu Bakr went out to trade in Busra, one year before the Prophet (ï·º) died, and with him were Nu`aiman and Suwaibit the sons of Harmalah, who had been present at Badr. Nu`aiman was in charge of the provisions, and Suwaibit was a man who joked a lot. He said to Nu`aiman: 'Feed me'. He said: 'Not until Abu Bakr comes'. He said: 'Then I will have to annoy you'. Then they passed by some people, and Suwaibit said to them: 'Will you buy a slave from me?' They said: 'Yes'. He said 'He is a slave who talks a lot and he will tell you, "I am a free man". If you are going to let him go when he says that to you, do not bother buying him.' They said: 'We will buy him from you.' So they bought him from him in return for ten young she-camels, then they brought him and tied a turban or a rope around his neck. Nu`aiman said: 'This man is making fun of you. I am a free man, not a slave.' They said: 'He has already told us about you; and they took him off.' Then Abu Bakr came and he (Suwaibit) told him about that. So he followed those people and returned their camels to them, and took Nu`aiman back. When they came to the Prophet (ï·º) they told him what had happened, and the Prophet (ï·º) and his companions laughed about it for a year."

(116)Chapter: What Has Been Related About Not Reciting Behind The Imam When The Imam Is Reciting Aloud


Jami` at-Tirmidhi 312
Abu Hurairah narrated:
"Allah's Messenger turned (after praying) from a Salat in which he recited aloud and said: 'Has any one of you recite along with me just now?' A man said: 'Yes, O Messenger of Allah.' He said: 'Indeed I said to myself: Why was I being contended with for the Quran?'" He (Az-Zuhri one of the narrators) said: "So when they heard that from Allah's Messenger, the people stopped reciting with Allah's Messenger in the prayers that Allah's Messenger recited aloud."

09/03/2025, 4:37â€¯pm - +91 97913 71056: Is the following Hadeeth and the explanation given with it authentic?
09/03/2025, 4:37â€¯pm - +91 97913 71056: Bad breath during Fasting:

Some people mistakenly think that the bad breath of the fasting person is a good thing, citing the Hadith: 

ÙˆÙÙ„ÙØ®ÙÙ„ÙÙˆÙÙ ÙÙÙ…Ù Ø§Ù„ØµÙ‘ÙØ§Ø¦ÙÙ…Ù Ø£ÙØ·Ù’ÙŠÙØ¨Ù Ø¹ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙÙ‡Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø±ÙÙŠØ­Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ³Ù’ÙƒÙ
"The smell of the mouth of a fasting person is better in the sight of God than the smell of musk (perfume)." 
["Sahih Bukhari", 5927].
https://sunnah.com/bukhari:5927

This is a wrong understanding of the Hadith.

It is talking about the odour that is generated by the empty stomach, it is not encouraging a lack of hygiene by not brushing your teeth. 

This misunderstanding arose at the time of Mu'adh Ibn Jabbal, and he corrected it:

The Prophet used to brush his teeth, when he was fasting. It is encouraged to brush the teeth during fasting even if its with toothpaste, as long as its not swallowed - according to many scholars.

This is especially important when you meet other people, attend gatherings and meetings, etc.

12/03/2025, 1:10â€¯pm - +966 50 527 3012: rule 7
12/03/2025, 1:40â€¯pm - +91 98744 95221: Males only
1) Try to send the narration in Arabic and text form so it's easier for me

2) Try to mention how you want the answer to be beforehand (summarised, takhrÄ«j, scan, voice message etc) to avoid back and forth and wastage of time

3) You are allowed only one question a day as checking authenticity takes time

4) Avoid discussions that are not related to authenticity. Take them to private

5) Try to consolidate your question in one single message, be clear and unambiguous 

6) Only admins are allowed to answer

7) Wait for the answer as tagging/reminders will not give a faster reply

Note: There can be a difference of opinion on grading but I won't necessarily mention it.
Corrections are welcome privately

*[Males only]*

1) Try to send the quote (Arabic preferably) in text form

2) Try to mention how you want the answer to be beforehand (summarised, takhrÄ«j, scan, voice message etc) to avoid back and forth and wastage of time

3) You are allowed only one question within 24H as checking authenticity takes time

5) Try to consolidate your question in one single message, be clear and unambiguous 

6) Only admins are allowed to answer

7) Wait for the answer instead of tagging/reminders as they will not give a quicker reply

01/04/2025, 5:41â€¯pm - +971 55 405 3501: translation of the whole point:
The Forty-Fourth Point: That Allah's pleasure with His servant is greater than Paradise and all that is in it. This is because pleasure (Ø±Ø¶Ø§) is an attribute of Allah, whereas Paradise is His creation. Allah, the Exalted, said:

"And the pleasure of Allah is greater." [At-Tawbah: 72]

This statement follows His words:

"Allah has promised the believing men and believing women Gardens beneath which rivers flow, wherein they will abide eternally, and pleasant dwellings in Gardens of perpetual residence. But the pleasure of Allah is greater. That is the supreme success." [At-Tawbah: 72]

This divine pleasure is a reward for their contentment with Him in this world. And since this reward is the greatest of all rewards, its cause must be the best of all deeds.

03/04/2025, 11:21â€¯pm - +91 80868 21261: Ziyadat al-Thiqah (Ø²ÙŠØ§Ø¯Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø«Ù‚Ø©) is an Arabic term meaning "the addition by a trustworthy narrator." In the science of Hadith (Islamic tradition studies), it refers to extra words or details in a narration that are reported by a reliable (thiqah) narrator but not found in other versions of the same Hadith.

Ruling on Ziyadat al-Thiqah:

1. Accepted (Maqbool) if it does not contradict stronger narrations â€“ If a trustworthy narrator adds extra information that aligns with established narrations, scholars generally accept it.


2. Rejected (Mardood) if it contradicts stronger narrations â€“ If the addition conflicts with more authentic or widely accepted reports, it is usually rejected.


3. Analyzed based on context â€“ Scholars compare the chain of narrators (isnad) and content (matn) to determine whether to accept or reject the addition.


Correct?

10/04/2025, 10:08â€¯pm - Muzammil New: *Here we distinguish between proven and unproven quotes/narrations*
*[Males only]*

1) Try to send the quote (Arabic preferably) in text form

2) Try to mention how you want the answer to be beforehand (summarised, takhrÄ«j, scan, voice message etc) to avoid back and forth and wastage of time

3) You are allowed only one question within 24H as checking authenticity takes time

4) Avoid messages that are not related to authenticity. Take them to private 

5) Try to consolidate your question in one single message, be clear and unambiguous 

6) Try to search (and mention) the reference beforehand (if possible) to reduce workload on the answerer. Please do not ask about quotes generated by AI

7) Wait for the answer instead of tagging/reminders as they will not give a quicker reply

*Note:* There can be a difference of opinion on the grading but I won't necessarily mention it.
Corrections are welcome privately

24/04/2025, 10:40â€¯pm - Muzammil New: *Here we distinguish between proven and unproven quotes/narrations*
*[Males only]*

1) Try to send the quote (Arabic preferably) in text form

2) Try to mention how you want the answer to be beforehand (summarised, takhrÄ«j, scan, voice message etc) to avoid back and forth and wastage of time

3) You are allowed only one question within 24H as checking authenticity takes time

4) Avoid messages that are not related to authenticity. Take them to private 

5) Try to consolidate your question in one single message, be clear and unambiguous 

6) Try to search (and mention) the reference beforehand (if possible) to reduce workload on the answerer. Please do not ask about quotes generated by AI

7) Wait for the answer instead of tagging/reminders as they will not give a quicker reply

*Note:* There can be a difference of opinion on the grading but I won't necessarily mention it.
Corrections are welcome privately

17/05/2025, 7:24â€¯pm - Muzammil New: *Here we distinguish between proven and unproven quotes/narrations*
*[Males only]*

1) Try to send the quote (Arabic preferably) in text form

2) Try to mention how you want the answer to be beforehand (summarised, takhrÄ«j, scan, voice message etc) to avoid back and forth and wastage of time

3) You are allowed only one question within 24H as checking authenticity takes time

4) Avoid messages that are not related to authenticity. Take them to private 

5) Try to consolidate your question in one single message, be clear and unambiguous 

6) Try to search (and mention) the reference beforehand (if possible) to reduce workload on the answerer. Please do not ask about quotes generated by AI

7) Wait for the answer instead of tagging/reminders as they will not give a quicker reply

*Note:* There can be a difference of opinion on the grading but I won't necessarily mention it.
Corrections are welcome privately

26/05/2025, 1:53â€¯pm - +92 334 3839983: The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) advised:

"If you hear the barking of dogs or the braying of donkeys at night, seek refuge in Allah, for they see what you do not."

Therefore, upon hearing dogs bark at night, it's recommended to say: "A'udhu billahi min ash-shaytan ir-rajim"

This means, "I seek refuge with Allah from Satan, the accursed."

This practice is a form of seeking protection from any potential harm from unseen forces

26/05/2025, 7:36â€¯pm - +91 63887 26284: The Reason Al-Shafi' Refuted Imam Malik: The People's Excessiveness Toward Malik

Al-Bayhaqi said:

I read in the book of Abu Yahya Zakariya ibn Yahya Al-Saji, in what the Egyptians narrated: That Al-Shafi'i only authored his refutation against Malik because it reached him that in Al-Andalus, there was a hat (qalansuwa) attributed to Malik and they would seek rain through it (i.e., treat it as a relic for seeking barakah).

And it was said to them: "The Messenger of Allah said..." - and they would respond: "Malik said..."

So Al-Shafi'i said:

"Malik is a human being; he may err and make mistakes."

What prompted him to write that book (against Malik's positions) was this reason.

He used to say: "I disliked doing this, but I sought guidance from Allah in this matter for such-and-such year." Narrated by Al-Saji

[Manaqib Al-Shafi'i by Al-Bayhaqi (1/508)]


Authentic?

Why is it called Arafah?

'Ata'a Ibn Rabah (rahimahullah d. 115 AH) said: It was termed "Arafah" because angel Jibreel (alaihisalam ) used to show Ibraheem (alaihisalam) the rites (of the pilgrimage). And he (Jibreel) would ask, "Arafata?" "Arafata?" "Did you understand?" "Did you understand?" So it was named "Arafah"

[Musannaf Ibn Abi Shaybah (rahimahullah) 14131].

02/07/2025, 9:47â€¯am - +92 300 8233395: *YOU WILL GET ADDICTED TO ISTIGHFAR AFTER READING THIS*

The Beautiful story of Imam Ahmad Ibn Hanbal and the Baker from Tafseer Al-Qurtubi Ø±Ø­Ù…Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ (18/301-302

During his old age, Imam Ahmad, a renowned scholar of Islam and a famous theologian, was traveling when he stopped by a town. After salah (prayer), he wanted to stay for the night in the mosque. Owing to his humility, he hadn't introduced himself to anyone thinking that if he did, he would be welcomed by many people.

Failing to recognize Ahmad bin Hanbal, the caretaker of the mosque refused to let him stay in the mosque. A baker, whose shop was nearby, watched this scene and took pity on Imam Ahmed. He invited the Imam to stay with him for the night.

He watched as the baker mixed and kneaded the dough, tended the fire, and pulled hot loaves from the oven, all the while uttering remembrances of Allah and Istighfar

In the morning, the Imam eagerly asked his host about the latter's continual istighfaar. The baker said it had become like second nature, and Imam Ahmad then asked whether the man had experienced any reward from this practice.

The baker answered, "By Allah! No dua I made except that it was answered but one." When Ibn Hanbal asked what that unanswered prayer was, the baker responded: "To see the famous Imam Ahmad ibn Hanbal."

At this, tears came to Ibn Hanbal's eyes and he told the baker, "I am Ahmed ibn Hanbal!" "By Allah! I was brought to your place so that you can have your dua/wish come true."

Memorizing the Qur'an After the Age of Fifty (50)

Shaykh 'Abd al-Mushin al-'Abbad - may Allah preserve and protect him - was asked in his home: Is an individual able to memorize the Qur'an after reaching the age of fifty?

He replied: Yes, and I am from those who memorized the Qur'an after the age of fifty! There were Companions (may Allah be pleased with them) who Islam reached them when they were older; despite that they memorized.

16th of Jumada al-Akhirah 1441H

Jabir ibn Abdullah al-Ansari and Abdullah ibn Abbas said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) was born on the Day of the Elephant, on Monday, the 12th of the month of Rabi' al-Awwal. On this day he was appointed as a prophet, on this day he ascended to the heavens, on this day he migrated, and on this day he passed away (peace and blessings be upon him)."

02/09/2025, 6:49â€¯pm - Muzammil New: *Advices from al-ShÄfi'Ä« when your friend does a mistake*

YÅ«nus ibn Ê¿Abd al-AÊ¿lÄ said that l-ShÄfiÊ¿Ä« said to me one day:
*O YÅ«nus, if you are informed of something you dislike about your friend, then beware of rushing to animosity and cutting the friendship bond, lest you become one of those who removed his certainty with a doubt. Rather, meet him and say to him: 'It has reached me about you such-and-such' and it is better that you name who informed you. If he denies it, then say to him: 'You are more truthful and more upright,' and do not add anything to that. And if he confesses to it and you see an excuse for it, then accept it from him. And if you do not see that, then say to him: 'What did you intend by what has reached me about you?' If he then mentions a matter as an excuse, accept it. And if he does not mention an excuse for it, and the path becomes constricted for you, then at that point establish it against him as a misdeed. Then, you have the choice: if you wish, you may repay him in equal without any addition, and if you wish, you may forgive him. And forgiveness is more conducive to TaqwÃ¡ and more profound in nobility due to the saying of AllÄh the Exalted: {And the recompense for an evil is an evil like thereof, but whoever pardons and makes reconciliation - his reward is from AllÄh} [al-ShÅ«rÄ: 40]. So, if your soul contests with you, urging for retaliation, then remember the good he did for you and do not diminish the remainder of his previous goodness because of this single misdeed for that is injustice in its very essence. And a righteous man used to say: 'May AllÄh have mercy on one who repaid me for my wrongdoing without adding to it, nor diminishing a right that was due to me.' O YÅ«nus, if you have a friend, hold fast to him with both your hands, for indeed, making a friend is difficult and parting from him is easy. And a righteous man used to compare the ease of parting from a friend to a young boy who throws a great stone into a well; its throwing is easy for him, but its removal is difficult even for strong, sturdy men. So this is my counsel to you. And SalÄm.*

04/09/2025, 5:44â€¯pm - +91 88229 56870: Imam ash-Shafi'ee - Poetry on how to respond to Fool:

"The fools speak to me with all vulgarity

So I hate to respond likewise in turn. they increase in their evil, so I increase in my patience"

Like an incense that becomes more fragrant when burned. So when the fool speaks do not respond, the strongest rebuttal is lack of acknowledgment.

If you address him he finds comfort, but if you ignore him he remains paralyzed

In another narration Imam ash-Shafi'i said: "If a fool speaks, do not answer him. The best answer to him is silence. If you answer him, it will only loosen his tongue. If you leave him, he will die of sadness."

Also ash-Shafi'i said: "A humiliation of knowledge is to argue with everyone who tries to argue with you, and to speak with everyone who tries to speak with you." "Manaqib ash-Shafi'i", 2/151,
